tagline: Codifying U.S. law in machine-executable form
body:
**The Hammurabi Project is an experiment in codifying U.S. law - such as the U.S. Code, the Code of Federal Regulations, state laws, etc. - in a machine-executable format.**

There are [millions](http://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text) [of](http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr&tpl=%2Findex.tpl) [pages](http://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/opinions.aspx) [of](http://scholar.google.com/scholar_courts?q=court) [law](http://law.justia.com/) with which Americans are expected to comply.

And though the law is massive and complicated, it is in many ways computational, specifying algorithms to be carried out, like: _What is my standard (tax) deduction_? _Am I eligible for family and medical leave_? _On what day did I become liable for unemployment taxes_?

Determinations such as these weave together into a [vast network of rules](https://github.com/mpoulshock/hammurabi/tree/master/Akkadian/Law), which can be compiled and embedded into our computing infrastructure to drive other software applications.

More information can be found on the [project wiki](https://github.com/mpoulshock/hammurabi/wiki).
